column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=4. Discussion
#Text=4.1. Biomass Can Indicate the Impact of Nitrogen on Grain Weight
#Text=As noted in previous studies , the strong correlation between above-ground biomass and grain weight (
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=A ) showed that biomass can be used as an indicator of grain weight responses to N in the six wheat genotypes evaluated in this experiment .
#Text=The relationship between above-ground biomass and grain weight is likely to be due to the positive correlation between leaf surface area and total photosynthesis per unit ground area .
#Text=Previous studies using destructive methods also showed a strong relationship between biomass and grain weight in both hard and soft wheat genotypes .
#Text=The high positive correlation between above-ground biomass and grain weight (
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=A ) is counteracted by the negative correlation between biomass and grain N % (
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=B , C ) .
#Text=Consequently , increasing grain weight appears to result in a grain N % penalty , particularly at low N.

#Text=The reduction in grain N % with increasing grain weight may reflect the high priority placed on elevating grain weight by wheat breeders rather than grain N % accumulation under low N conditions .
#Text=The results suggest that once the maximum level of grain weight has been achieved , the additional N is invested in increasing grain N % , particularly , for high GPC genotypes .
#Text=The relatively low grain N % seen for all varieties in this study (
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=A – C ) may be due to the favourable growth conditions in the greenhouse and , consequent , increase in biomass .

#Text=It appears that the high N requirements of plants seen in this experiment , meant that the applied N at low and medium N was mostly used for grain weight production rather than to increase grain N % .
#Text=4.2. Differences in Nitrogen Responsiveness between High and Low GPC Genotypes
#Text=Spitfire and Mace produced less biomass at low N than the other genotypes and were more responsive at high N compared with the low grain N % genotypes (
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=A and
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=G – I ) .
#Text=Related studies on wheat and oilseed spring rape indicate that genotypes , which show reduced yield at low N may show greater responses to higher N levels compared to other genotypes .
#Text=It is shown that high compared to low GPC wheat genotypes require higher N rates to show favourable yield responses .
#Text=In accordance with previous studies , reducing N supply diminished the total biomass and growth rate .
#Text=However , by reducing N inputs , biomass and growth rate declined more in high than in low grain N concentration genotypes .
#Text=In fact , the biomass of genotypes that were selected for high GPC was more vulnerable to low N in comparison with the biomass of low GPC genotypes (
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=A ,
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=, and
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=G – I ) .
#Text=The high reduction of biomass growth in high GPC genotypes at low N was previously observed in wheat .
#Text=In high GPC genotypes , biomass growth under limited N may be reduced in favour of root growth to support N uptake after anthesis .
#Text=This study showed that shortening t-maxAGR was the key limiting factor for PSA production for high grain N genotypes (
#Text=Figure 6
#Text=A ) .
#Text=In other words , high N genotypes appear to reach the peak of growth and terminate the vegetative stage earlier in low N than high N-treated plants (
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=B ,
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=and Table 1 ) .
#Text=Compressing phenology at low N , which decreases N requirement , has been previously observed in different species .
#Text=However , the low impact of N shortage on the t-maxAGR and biomass growth of Gazelle and QAL2000 was a new finding in this study .
#Text=Our results indicated that the rate of t-maxAGR reduction from high to low N was related to the grain N concentration ( Table 1 and
#Text=Figure 6
#Text=A – C ) .
#Text=Spitfire and Mace had higher grain N than Gazelle and QAL2000 , and appeared to demand more N to grow their biomass .
#Text=It might be that high grain N % genotypes sense the low N status early in development and shorten their vegetative growth phase to maintain sufficient N for grain development and filling .
#Text=Hence , Spitfire responded to low N by reducing growth rate , possibly to conserve N for grains (
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=B and Table 1 ) .
#Text=In this context , the grain N % of Spitfire and Mace were not influenced by t-maxAGR at different N treatments (
#Text=Figure 7
#Text=A , B ) .
#Text=Therefore , high grain N % genotypes in this study were able to prevent grain N loss at low N conditions regardless of the variations in the time to maximum absolute growth rate .
#Text=Accelerating the life cycle is a typical response of plants to low N.
#Text=N translocation corresponds with senescence since senescing leaf and stem tissues are an important N source for grains .

#Text=Therefore , the increase of shoot biomass and carbon assimilation after flowering can compete with grain demand for N. In Gazelle and QAL2000 , which are genotypes used for low GPC purposes , low N supply did not trigger accelerated development and a decrease in the time to maxAGR (
#Text=Figure 6
#Text=C ) .
#Text=This suggests that Gazelle and QAL2000 use the available N primarily for biomass production and do not show the conservative strategy used by Spitfire and Mace .
